Human: Why is every book I hear about a " NY Times # 1 Best Seller " ? ELI5 : Why is every book I hear about a " NY Times # 1 Best Seller " ? Should n't there only be one " # 1 " best seller ? Please explain like I'm five.

Assistant:
predict:
is every book  I hear  about  a " NY Times # 1 Best Seller "?

ELI5:  Why is every book  I hear about  a " NY Times # 1 Best Seller "?
Shouldn't there only be one "# 1" best seller?

Answer: This question has more to answer than just saying that there is only one best seller per category per bookstore. (For one thing, Amazon, not the NYT, does rankings on its site, and they are also pretty prominent and frequently cited.)

There's at least half a dozen reasons why.

The first is that, for all the crap talk books in "Amazon Echo Chamber" of people who use social media to complain about the world and make up outrage to get clicks, there's a real contingent of book sales made thanks to social media. For some people (I know two authors who do this) they will use social media as their platform for promoting their books.

The next is that authors now do much more marketing on their own. For authors, the idea that the publicist and the publisher will actually market their book is a joke. It's almost impossible for the publisher to push anyone's book into the top ten, and the only way you'd get anyone to actually notice you at all would be for the publisher to say "Hey everybody, go get his book." Which is to put it mildly difficult now with how much the publishers have been decimated and the corporation of Amazon taking over publishing. Now you have to do it yourself, and one of the best ways to market yourself or your book is get an interview for a radio or TV show or get a quote on news articles or something else. It's the same way you'd get yourself, your business, or your product to be featured on a talk show, which you may or may not remember is a book, an Amazon Best Seller or #1 in an Amazon category.

The other thing is that many of the books listed are not necessarily physical books available for sale. A lot of authors and publishers do what they call a book promotion where they give physical books for sale away for free as long as you're a subscriber. Like you register for a free account on their site and receive a free physical copy of my book. Or you have to enter a contest for the chance to win one. Or you can donate to charity to get a physical copy. They don't necessarily sell the book on site because often they want to create demand or do some kind of giveaway.

Now at least some of those books never even make it onto the site and aren't tracked.

The last thing is that the Amazon Bookstores, which is separate from the main Amazon site, uses other criteria to determine the top selling book. Their criteria has very loose and easy to cheat with goals that encourage people to cheat at their books, because their business model is entirely different than Amazon's.

Comment: @JoeKing Everyone gets to decide what the criteria of a best seller means, and people have always found loopholes in that criteria (like when they count in sales of digital books).

Comment: No offence, but I am pretty sure most people here are not Amazon insiders. So how can someone answer OP's question better than the best person on here who is able to answer it with sufficient detail?!

Comment: OP is saying that there are a lot of books on the charts but only one best seller. In any chart, yes there are always many books close to the top, but a #1 doesn't mean the best, it means the first position on the list. The term you're looking for is top seller. A "Best Seller" is the product with highest average rating in a category.

Comment: Someone asked a question that might contain a scientific misunderstanding.  A more helpful response would be to say "This is not a research paper.  You should explain this in layman's terms without scientific details."

Answer: This is a scientific paper, so there should be no such things as "cultural", only scientific or human. In the field of economics there are many theories about why production takes the shape it does. In the [first-order theory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Production_function#First-order_theory), product quality is an important driver of decisions about how a product should be built. [Hicks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hicks_Law) found that better quality was associated with higher production costs but higher productivity and thus lower price.

The assumption is that producers would choose a product mix that minimizes costs, so the mix that makes an object that is not worth fixing vs. another that is, is taken into account. These models are often used to find optimal strategies for government policy that support the industry.

The [second-order theory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Production_function#Second-order_theory) of production assumes that products have quality attributes that are not captured in the direct measures and is usually used to study how products are priced in terms of quality as a differentiator. Here, the "cultural" side of consumption and product ownership comes into play.

So, if your question is: what causes the price of products to vary in way so consumers can choose between fixing an item instead of replacing it, the second-order theory would be more appropriate to explain the consumer's behavior. That said, [consumption](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consumer_theory) theories would need to be brought in to the analysis as well.

Answer: In economics, we talk about demand and supply curves. The curves are based upon utility of the end products, i.e., if you demand a new product and the other side of the market supplies such the curve shifts.

You may consider two approaches, as follows:

If you are in a competitive market, i.e., the suppliers are a number of players and do not affect the price due to monopoly or duopoly or oligopoly etc., then, there will be no difference in the end product because all are trying to sell at the lowest price. If, the suppliers of a product decide to charge higher prices, say, for repair of mobile phone, then, people will switch to other products even for mobile phones.

However, if you are in a differentiated market, i.e., if you are not forced to buy a cheap mobile but you can choose a brands that offers better quality, then, you can differentiate between repair or replacement of broken/damaged mobile phone. This is, however, dependent upon supply side, cost of maintenance, market share.

If the economies of scale make it cheaper for a supplier then the price will come down. However, if it is difficult to produce the materials to make such a product cheaper then the price will be much higher. If there is a lack of raw materials, the price will be higher.

Moreover, the cost to produce the products will also matter and the profit from that product. This will be directly dependent upon competition.

However, the demand side will also play an important role in the matter, i.e., consumers behavior to use that product or replace it. This will be dependent upon their value to them.

As you can see, there are a number of things that play a dominant role.

Human: What are prions and are they a big deal ? My AP Biology teacher mentioned them alongside viruses but he did n't say much else beyond that they are n't viruses and they deform protein structure . Please explain like I'm five.

Assistant:
predict:
re is only one species of prion, and it has been described as the causal agent of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease in humans. It is also the cause of'mad cow disease' in cattle. There is also a sporadic form of this disease. This disease is not very easy to transmit between humans, although there is a documented case of trans-species contagion in humans who worked with'mad cow disease' in the United Kingdom. To understand the effect that prions have, one must understand that aminoacyl tRNA synthetases bring in the correct amino acid to be included in protein synthesis. When these are not working correctly, the resulting polymer is an abnormal and deadly type of protein that is resistant to many solvents, including detergents and heat. This abnormal protein has been observed in the retinas of'mad cow's' brains. The protein is not alive, but it is able to cause the deadly disease. A protein-free solution can be made to test for these protein-polymers. In humans, the infection can cause the disease to progress quickly, and the abnormal proteins tend to be observed in the brain quickly. This can cause a wide range of mental confusion and memory loss to the infection. If this disorder is caught early enough, there may be a cure for humans who have this disease. However, this is very difficult since testing for the disorder is very invasive and requires tissue samples.

Human: What is a hacker really doing ? I 've always wanted to know why hackers are jamming on their keyboards and what they can possibly be doing that requires such precision and speed . Please explain like I'm five.

Assistant:
predict:
e term “hacker” has a lot of different connotations, depending on the context, who is using the term, and also the era it was coined.

When computers appeared on the scene in the 1960’s they were mostly used by scientists and mathematicians to calculate massive equations. They were expensive, complicated machines with limited functionality that were generally off-limits to the public.

In the 1970’s some people started calling themselves “Hackers” to emphasize how smart they were and to give themselves a name because they didn’t want to be considered criminals or vandals.

In the 1980’s Hackers became more involved in illegal activity such as breaking into computer systems, writing viruses, and cracking passwords to steal information.

In the 1990’s groups started to crop up online and eventually some of these groups turned into organized hacking rings that were motivated by financial gain.

The term “Hacker” is generally used to describe a person who breaks into computer systems without permission by using technical skills. Some people don’t fit the definition because they don’t want their activity to be considered criminal, but they still break into systems even though they know it’s illegal. Some of these hackers might be more technically skilled than others, but it does not necessarily make one a “Superhacker” for example.

The term “Superhacker” is not really used to describe a specific individual, it’s more of an idea that exists in movies and books where a group of hackers get together and start hacking into things that nobody has ever seen a computer be able to do before.

Hacking in movies or books is normally presented as a skill set that you can either have or not have, and once someone is considered to have the skill they are able to do all kinds of things very quickly and easily.

In reality not only would it be hard for a group of friends to get together and start performing complicated tasks that would appear as “super hacks” in a movie but also hacking these kinds of large scale operations would be very difficult for someone without a lot of experience in computer security and networking.


### In real life, when the term “hacker” is used by people who are not computer scientists it has a negative connotation to it.

This is not to say there aren’t very skilled individuals out there who can hack into someones computer and destroy their security systems, there’s plenty of those. The difference between a hacker and a criminal is that a hacker is someone who is using their skills to harm the person whose computer they’ve broken into for their own purposes, generally non-financial.

To prevent this kind of activity one should maintain a certain level of security awareness.


If you don't want to be called a hacker, it's your fault. It's your attitude.

Answer: \begin{blockquote}

Human: Why do movie companies build sets rather than film on scene?
\end{blockquote}

Some reasons are :
\begin{itemize}
\item Shooting on set gives them more control over the look, lighting and layout of the scene, which helps them keep their story on brand
\item If they use a real location, they can only come back to that location once and there is an additional risk of damages
\item The crew can work on more than one scene and it allows them to build up more of a scene together. This can also be a benefit if they need to film in multiple locations, which might not be safe or economical for the actors to commute
\item On a set, everything is in the same location so they can have better continuity
\end{itemize}

Hope this helps answer your questions!

Comment: While the set may be safer and allow more control over lighting, there are definitely some locations that are more convenient, cheaper, and just as safe for filming.

Intrinsic Value: is the actual value of everything that a company owns, which includes assets, liabilities, equity and income. These values should be calculated before a dividend is declared or paid as the stock's dividend could be included in the company's income.

Comment: Please note that Tor Browser does not do  "connection tunneling", in other words Tor Browser creates two TCP sockets with the exit node, one where it expects HTTP traffic and the other where it expects arbitrary traffic. However your Tor is still subject to [SOCKS proxy attack](https://security.stackexchange.com/questions/37550/can-my-socks-proxy-be-hacked/37553#37553).

Comment: @Rafał Latoszek Oh. This is bad. I have seen my own proxy logs and it shows that the proxy was used to connect to certain sites and I'm quite sure it's due to javascript libraries used in these pages. So do you mean that these attacks are not applicable to Tor?

Comment: @RafałLatoszek Oh, I see. If that's the case then maybe there is no way to actually anonymize with a proxy without creating a completely independent network [ like Orbot ]. I 'll try to find a way to fix these bugs and find a way to make my proxy reliable.

Comment: @KennyLau Orbot is not a proxy, it uses Tor as the proxy. But yes you can use Javascript libraries to hide your real IP address.

Answer: Javascript is not the answer (not even an answer) to the question of browser anonymity.  Javascript libraries like the one you're using do not actually encrypt your traffic, they just forward your traffic over to the Tor network and modify it in the process.  This means that it's still just that: Modifying your traffic.  If you're not using Tor, there are no layers of encryption or encryption in motion to actually secure your traffic.

Javascript libraries just forward your traffic over to the Tor network and then your original content is forwarded through your (anonymous) Tor exit node's traffic.

Also, this:

\begin{code}
request to www.google.com returns "200

request to http://127.0.0.1:123456/some_site.com returns "204
\end{code}

I think you have it backwards.  Your Tor exit node should be responding to the first request (with a 2XX), and anything else is a local request to a non-tor 127.0.0.1:123456.  Also, if Tor is able to communicate back to your browser at all for those responses, you're not using your Tor browser.  (And what exactly is happening in the browser when you've connected to 127.0.0.1:123456 and not Tor's proxy, and does nothing at all happen when you're proxying through Tor?)

Lastly, javascript libraries that proxy your traffic have many issues:

[Proxying all traffic could be a privacy risk](http://arstechnica.com/information-technology/2011/07/onion-routing-proxy-network-

Assistant:
predict:
can't get an adequate understanding of your question because this is too broad.

>   Try using a different tone when asking your question. e.g. be specific
>

I know, I was trying my best.

Comment: There is no way I can explain why mixing colors works as it does if I don't know what you know: i.e. I can't see what you see. The colors you see are a *personal percepstion* and can't be explained in terms of physics, but have to be described in terms of the signals your two retina detectors send to your brain and which are interpreted.

Comment: You might find some more details or perhaps some help with how exactly the human perception can be explained in more details with the 5 senses and the associated nerves https://physics.stackexchange.com/questions/99666/how-does-human-vision-work-physically?rq=1
. You can also follow up by asking your question to the people answering your question in comments to see if anything helps.

Answer: You are seeing different wavelengths of light. An object in the color green reflects that specific wavelength of light and you perceive it as green.

With paint, the color green is mixed with other colors so that it's no longer so easily visible. Red paint, reflects different wavelengths of light and so you perceive it's brown.

You could mix red and green paint, and end up with a very faint green-brown color. The green would still be mixed with other colors from the paints and not as distinct.

The color you see with paint or fabric or other objects is determined by the wavelengths reflected off the objects.

Answer: There are two things going on here, both involve the term \strong{refracting light} which can also go by the fancy term of \strong{diffraction}, I recommend reading up on both if you do not know them.
\begin{itemize}
\item Firstly the scattering of light inside the clouds is refracting the light, i.e. the light is refracted because you see it is no longer straight but curved when it enters the clouds.
\item Secondly the clouds are refracting the light and diffusing it because it's cloud is not uniform and so light is not reflected uniformly which causes the light to become scattered and we call this thing that happens \strong{diffusion}, and when light becomes scattered and we can not see the direction of the light this is also referred to as \strong{diffuse reflectivity}.
\end{itemize}

I hope that helps, if not then maybe do a search on how diffraction and diffuse reflectivity works.

Answer: A [cloud](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cloud) can be opaque, making the sun visible, and also transparent, so it is possible to see the sun through the cloud. For this answer, I assume a [stratus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stratiform_cloud) cloud.

A large part of a stratus cloud is in the form of tiny droplets of liquid water. These are just big enough and thin enough to transmit sunlight; the light just passes right through them. The smaller the droplets, the stronger the light throughput. If the droplets are extremely small, there is no transmission.

When a stratus cloud is thick enough, light from the sun will either pass through the cloud with no changes, or there will be such a lot of reflected light that we cannot see the sun.

So, if the cloud is thin, it only covers part of the sun, so we see the cloud as white. If the cloud if thick, it covers the sun, and we cannot see the sun, so it is dark.

Answer: \begin{blockquote}
Human: How does Amazon get their items shipped to your house so quickly, no matter what it is?
\end{blockquote}

I can only tell you from the company perspective as an ex C-Level executive at one of their prime customers of 21 years.

There is no way Amazon ships anything from any fulfillment center to a customer's home, except via Fed Ex, UPS, the Post Office, or common carrier truck.

There are a few exceptions to this I can think of, but those are exceptions that prove the rule.

One of the exceptions is that Amazon has a pilot program to offer same day shipping on some items, but that is only offered where they can deliver that same day in a one- or two-hour delivery window.
This is not what the OP was talking about, but I wanted to show that there is a small exception the rule (I would have explained some of the details for these special circumstances, but it would have made this answer too long and would not be understood by someone who is asking a five year old question).

The answer is that Amazon ships everything by UPS, and sometimes, by Fed Ex, depending on which Prime shipping option is chosen.

There is nothing Amazon sells and ships from their own fulfillment center to an Amazon Prime member's door.

Answer: Child actors may have one of three kinds of relationship to the production team (in no particular order):
\begin{itemize}
\item Their parents are managing their career.
\item One of the parents is managing their career, but not necessarily the one that's their legal guardian.  This is, in my experience, \em{much} more frequent than #1.
\item Their \em{legal} caretaker has contracted services from an agency that is managing their career.
\end{itemize}

In some cases, the children were born to a member of the production team.  While it may be possible to sign away their liabilities (such as medical care), the legal guardian of the child should be a member of their extended family.  That way they can be given the best care.

In New York City, the average monthly rent cost is about $2,500 for a one-bedroom apartment (http://www.apartmentlist.com/RENTCafé). On top of that you'll also have to pay utilities, which would likely to cost you $150-200/month plus food, transportation and other necessities, like healthcare, clothing, etc. So by adding it all together and dividing it all up by the amount you get paid every two weeks, it comes out to $216/day. That amount of money per day only leaves about $165/day left to spend.

This is a very bare-bones estimate -- a lot of people don't need to spend as much on things like healthcare, or they may have roommates to split rent in half, or have a more affordable place to live, but it highlights that $12,753/salary

**[🧠 Human](https://www.wolframalpha.com/input?i=why+why+double+) can't define what's this is. Assistant will.**

Double jeopardy is a principle of law under which a person who has already been tried for one offence and not convicted cannot be tried again for that offence. There is no limit in the United Kingdom as to how much money the government can take from you, only on how much they can take per year.

Comment: "He" for inanimate objects seems to originate from 1890s. But "she" was used for inanimate objects as long as they were humanised, so for a car, a ship or a house in most cases (or any object that looked like a human). So it was just general language usage. Since "it" is too cold and "one" too formal, it's "she". You can read more on "its" here: http://www.grammarphobia.com/blog/2014/12/it-s-wild.html "As for an inanimate nouns, like car, desk or bridge, it's been "he" since the 1890s. In fact those inanimate nouns sometimes have gender. The Empire State Building was a "she." The first person to use "it" in English in 1825 was George Bernard Shaw, who used it as a polemical device."

Answer: To be honest, I'm a guy, but I refer to things as "it" all the time. For instance:
\begin{itemize}
\item "Wow, I'm so bad at this game of Tetris. If it were easier, I could use a larger board, for instance." I think the fact that I'm male doesn't influence my language.
\end{itemize}

So, I actually don't buy into this, especially considering the fact that men refer to dogs and cars as "she."

You seem to be trying to say that there's a specific rule that's different for men vs. women, but that's what I was raised to call all inanimate objects, even though I'm a guy. I don't think either gender is consciously aware of the gender of the inanimate object; it's just the case of what we're used to saying.

It is true that we're conditioned to think that males are typically inanimate objects, but it's much more subtle than that.

Think about words like, "he or his" and what we say in casual conversation. When you say "We didn't see his friend; he was home from school." "Home" is male, right? "she or hers" (for the object the friend belongs to) is female? "The car broke." "it" is masculine... "a boat" is masculine.... "a car" is feminine....

You can even see this in words like "man" and "woman," which have become the "generic human."

Most inanimate objects do not have gender. If anything, the gender is often masculine due to the object being something that belongs to a male. If we're talking about a computer, then maybe "he" is better, but most people don't refer to computers this way.

\begin{blockquote}

Most modern English speakers who refer to inanimate objects using a third-person reflexive pronoun believe that they are acting out a tradition. For many, it stems from a conscious or subconscious belief that an object is female when it is unowned and/or unaccompanied by an inappropriate opposite-gendered pronoun. For instance, one might say "That car runs great!" and not "He runs great!" or "That ship runs great!" and not "She runs great!" This suggests that people think things are female due to a lack of association with a particular gender, not just femininity.
\end{blockquote}

"Why don't we say computer is'she' and then it becomes female because people aren't comfortable saying computer is'he'?"

Well think about it like this. The computer's gender seems irrelevant (as mentioned in the paragraph above). However, I'm a young person, and when I bought my computer, I knew it to be a masculine object. So, just to be sure, I call the computer "he."

I don't think men have any other motive for doing this other than to be polite to

Since the earth was not turning water would seep up through the soil towards the surface of the earth. And hence rivers, creeks, streams, oceans will all drain out from the earth's surface at various places and would eventually flow into the oceans at the poles, where oceans are present.

Now if Earth's rotation stopped abruptly, it would continue to move along its orbit around the Sun, but it would be sitting there stationary.

All the gases suspended in the atmosphere would all rush down to the ground and create a huge hurricane like situation.
And since the air would not be moving in the normal direction because of the Earth's rotation, there would be no up or down.

Answer: A large portion of lift in a plane is from the Bernoulli effect. That is, air passing over the wing above the body of the plane is going to push it up in a way.

But because wings are large, they need a "spillover" of air on the top and bottom to keep the air "flowing" the same way.

Therefore, if you had 4 wings all connected together, most of the air would be spilled over two of the wings, leaving little or no lift to the 2nd and 3rd wings.

Answer: The answer is gravity. It's actually pretty well understood why an airplane wing produces lift. (It's not just about Bernoulli) And while you can use a fan/propulsion device to produce lift, without gravity and the Bernoulli effect it would be very inefficient compared to a wing.

So, while in theory you could use four wings, they would have to be angled away from the center line (in the same way that an airplane's horizontal stabilizer is actually angled away from the main wings). This would produce an upward net thrust on the wings, which would be very unstable. In practice, it would also be quite inefficient (the air would have to be pushed very hard through the gaps in the wings).

Comment: The question wasn't about propulsion.

Answer: Four wings would take up the same aerodynamic area as two wings, but only produce about half the lift.  This is because the air has to flow past the sides of the wings to form lift, and the flow around a four winged wing is less efficient, and thus produces less lift.

Answer: You need to understand the theory (I mean not just what they teach us in school, but why airplanes fly).

The key is: There is more pressure over moving objects than there is under those objects (assumed at rest). This is because the air gets spread out more before encountering an object of fixed length, and the object of course has to have enough space left around it for it to not run into it. The force acting on an (infinite) object is the velocity component: (velocity)2/2. But that object can't be infinite, so it has to keep some small part of the distance (say, 1 nm) of the square. So only the first derivative of the pressure acts on it, if it moves in the direction opposite to 1 nm per sec.
